title: Liverpool would have been destroyed if Jurgen Klopp had shown doubt during their miserable January, admits Georginio Wijnaldum
text:

Jurgen Klopp's Liverpool revolution could have been killed off before it truly got started... but for the unshakable faith of the manager. 
That is the view of Reds midfielder Giorginio Wijnaldum, who admitted they were suffering a crisis of faith during that miserable January run which destroyed their chances of winning a trophy this season. 
No league wins since the turn of the year, exits from both domestic Cups and just one victory in 10 matches tested the mental strength and spirit of the team manager Klopp is building, before a spectacular revival against Tottenham on Saturday. 
Wijnaldum conceded the run almost destroyed the team - and could easily have done, had their passionate manager not stuck so determinedly to his belief in the players to defy the critics who said the squad isn't good enough. January 25: Southampton knock Liverpool out at the EFL Cup's semi-final stage (Photo: BPI) January 28: Championship Wolves win at Anfield in the FA Cup (Photo: Getty) 
"You really feel it on a run like that - I think in some situations we put too much pressure on ourselves and that is why it went so wrong," the Netherlands international explained. 
"That is why it was really important the manager believes in us. 
"If a manager says the same (as the critics) in the situation we are in now, that is killing for a team. It would kill the confidence of the players. 
"When you are a team, you have to believe in each other. You are a kind of family and if one of yours says, 'You’re not good enough’ or what the media has been saying, that is not a good thing. January 2: Lowly Sunderland twice hit back from a goal down to draw with Klopp's men (Photo: Getty) January 15: Liverpool lead Man United at Old Trafford, but concede a late equaliser (Photo: Getty) January 21: Then-bottom side Swansea stun Anfield with a 3-2 away win (Photo: Getty) 
"He believes in us and I don’t think he just said it because he wanted to keep the confidence, I think he truly believes it. 
"That gave us a good feeling." 
Klopp has worked hard to foster that sense of family within his side, because he knows it can be a potent weapon against the big beasts of the Premier League who have greater financial resources than the Anfield outfit. 
But even his faith was tested during a dry January when the wheels came off Liverpool's title challenge - and suggested there were big problems within the squad. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
